revised_title: Explaining Ball-and-Socket Jointing in Basalt Prisms
tldr: The author explains the phenomenon of ball-and-socket jointing in basalt prisms, which occurs when basalt columns are chilled on the outside while the inside remains hot. This causes tension in the outer layers, leading to cracks that form at right angles to the length of the column. The author provides a detailed explanation of how these cracks develop into the characteristic ball-and-socket or basin-like shape, and how the surrounding cooling medium plays a crucial role in the process.
